flow.descriptionCdata:
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.057e5198-eedd-4a3e-89c4-3d55a2fa734a.description=
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    field1 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field2 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field3 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field4 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the value of  "field1" as it was specified at input or when filtered. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.0fc3ec57-94e7-41de-afb6-84138113302f.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and 
returns the keys of the object as a JSON array.
A JSON object is an unordered set of key/value pairs, therefore the order of the keys returned is arbitrary.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA".  This operation
would return keys "city", "state".

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object. 
      The operation will return a failure if it is not a JavaScript object.

Responses

   success
      The keys of the object were successfully returned, in arbitrary order.

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation.  You may wish to use a
      tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

     The primary output will be the keys of the object, in arbitrary order.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.2ce20729-0437-480e-ba7d-a7f962182eff.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and
returns a value for the specified key.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA". This operation would 
return "Palo Alto" if user enters "city" as a key.

If the input object contains JSON array, array index can be used in the key input. For example, 
{ "location"\: [
      {"city"\: "Roseville", "country"\: "United States"},
      {"city"\: "Cluj", "country"\: "Romania"},
      {"city"\: "Yehud", "country"\: "Israel"}]    
}
The operation would return "Roseville" if user enters "location[0].city" as a key.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object.  
      The operation will return a failure if it is not a JavaScript object.

   key
      The key in the object to get the value of.

Responses

   success
      The value was successfully returned for the specified key. 

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation or the specified key does not exist in the object.  
      You may wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   The primary output will be the value for the specified key in the object.

Note

    If the value in JSON object is in scientific notation, the returned output will be converted to an equivalent decimal number. Ex, 2.9e+1 will be converted to 29.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.313ca783-adce-464e-a695-f25c599c0771.description=

Displays a message to the user.

Inputs\:
  message - The message text to display
  title - The title on the message window. Defaults to "Status message".

Responses\:
  Always returns success.

Examples\:
  In order to display the message "Finished" to the user, go to the 
  detail screen for the input named "message" and change the Otherwise option
  from Prompt User to Use Constant.  Then enter the text "Finished" into the
  Constant Value field.

  References to flow variables in the Contant Value field are expanded so that
  the text may be dynamic.  Flow variable references are of the form
  ${variable}.  For example, the text\:
     ${count} systems were modified 
  could be used to display a message about the number of systems that were
  repaired, whose value is in the flow variable "count".

  When the message is displayed, it will properly render any embedded html
  tags, which permits creating messages with more advanced formatting.  For 
  example to display a message in italics you could use\:
    This is important
  or to display a message in red\:
    This is really  important

  You can create messages that contain multiple lines by entering a multiple
  line message in the Constant Value field, or by using HTML 
 tags for line
  breaks.  Note that \n characters are displayed literally and are not used for
  creating multiple lines.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.422e36be-0890-42f7-b957-af7c3458df5a.description=Inserts a new name/value property into a JSON object, where the value is a string. This operation forces the value of the name/vale pair to be a string, no matter what data type it actually is. This means that the input does not need to be wrapped in quotes as any quotes entered in this input will be escaped, ending up in the properties' value. The 'Add JSON Property to Object' operation should be used to add values of type other than string, for example\: another object, an array or a number. Examples\: 1) Inputs\: jsonObject\: {} newPropertyName\: test newPropertyValue\: test_value Result\: { "test"\:"test_value"} 2) Inputs\: jsonObject\: {} newPropertyName\: test newPropertyValue\: "test_value" Result\: { "test"\:"\"test_value\""} 3) Inputs\: jsonObject\: {} newPropertyName\: test newPropertyValue\: 1 Result\: { "test"\:"1"} 4) Inputs\: jsonObject\: {} newPropertyName\: test newPropertyValue\: [1,2,3,4] Result\: { "test"\:"[1,2,3,4]"} Note the value in the name/value pair above is not a JSON Array, but a plain string that looks like one. Inputs\: jsonObject - String representation of a JSON object. Objects in JSON are a collection of name value pairs, separated by a colon and surrounded with curly brackets {}. The name must be a string value, and the value can be a single string or any valid JSON object or array. Examples\: {"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, {"one"\:{"a"\:"a","B"\:"B"}, "two"\:"two", "three"\:[1,2,3.4]} newPropertyName - The name of the new property to add to the JSON object. Examples\: property1, some_property, another property newPropertyValue - The value for the new property. This is interpreted as a string, no matter what the contents of the input. Examples\: value1, another value Results\: Result - The JSON array with the inserted element. Responses\: success - The operation completed as stated in the description. failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully. See the message in for details. adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.82a8e7a3-a80a-4601-8821-9d0420004f1d.description=
Insert an object into a JSON array, optionally specifying the position at which to insert the new object. 

This Operation differes from the 'Add to Array' operation in that this one will try and validate the new element as
a JSON object, whereas 'Add to Array' will just wrap the element in quotes and treat it as a string. This means 
that the element passed into this operation must be a valid JSON object, or the operation will fail. 

When specifying the index to an array element in javascript it is possible to use the standard notation, where the 1st 
element from the left is index 0, and the right-most element is (n-1), in an array with n elements. However, 
it is also possible to specify elements starting from the right side of the array using negative numbers, in which case
the right-most element is referred to by index -1 and the left-most element is at position (-1 * n), again for an array with n elements.

Inputs\:
    array - String representation of a JSON array. Arrays in JSON are comma seperated lists of objects, enclosed in square brackets ( [ ] ).
Examples\: [1,2,3] or ["one","two","three"] or [{"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, 3, "four"]

    element - The element to insert into the array. As noted above, this must be a valid JSON object or the operation will fail. It can be 
                    any valid JSON object; such as a number, string, an array, or a name/value pair list. Numbers can be entered as-is, strings
                    must be wrapped in quotes, and objects must be formated correctly (see examples below for more info)
Valid values\: Any valid JSON object
Examples\: 1 or "a string" or {"one"\:"two", "three"\:"four"} or [1,2,3]

    index -The index in the array at which to insert the new element. If index is undefined, or index is equal to the length of the array 
               (one past the last element), the new element is placed at the end of the array. See the notes above for more information
               on using negative numbers to specify array elements.
               If the index is valid, the new element is inserted at that position, and all remaining elements are shifted one position to the right.

Valid values\: Integer between (-1*n) and (n-1) for an array with n elements.
Default value\: undefined (insert the new element at the end of the array)


Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation failed. See the message in returnResult for details


Results\:
    returnResult - The new JSON array with the inserted element.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.94cb5c06-51e6-4853-a7ba-b0dac4e347d6.description=
Inserts a new name/value property into a JSON object, where the value is a valid JSON string. If the  input is not a valid string representation of a JSON object, the operation fails.

The 'Add Property to Object' operation can be used to add a property with a simple string value. 

Examples\: 
1)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: [1,2,3]
     Result\:
         { "test"\:[1,2,3]}
2)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: {"a"\:"b"}
     Result\:
         { "test"\:{"a"\:"b"}}
3)
    Inputs\:
        jsonObject\: {}
        newPropertyName\: test
        newPropertyValue\: 1
     Result\:
         { "test"\:1}

Inputs\:
    jsonObject - String representation of a JSON object. Objects in JSON are a collection of name value pairs, separated by a colon and surrounded with curly brackets {}. The name must be a string value, and the value can be a single string or any valid JSON object or array.
Examples\: {"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, {"one"\:{"a"\:"a","B"\:"B"}, "two"\:"two", "three"\:[1,2,3.4]}
    newPropertyName - The name of the new property to add to the JSON object. 
Examples\: property1, some_property, another property
    newPropertyValue - The value for the new property. This must be a valid JSON representation of a JavaScript object.
Examples\: 1, {"A"\:"A"}, [1,2,3,4]

Results\:
    Result - The JSON array with the inserted element.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully. See the message in  for details.
adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.96be1005-3191-49f3-84c4-7fb47bcfe9c4.prompt=Enter if the post is completed adab30cc-a507-4e46-9260-13f0f0e4a7fb.bb148f28-b009-4015-980c-2adbdd941d74.description=
This operation takes a reference to JSON (in the form of a string) and runs a specified JSON Path query on it. It returns the results as a JSON Object. 

Inputs\:
    json - The JSON in the form of a string.
    jsonPathQuery - The JSON Path query to run. See details and examples in the Notes section below.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the resulted JSON from the given path.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1.Query syntax\:
JSONPath 		Description
------------                           -------------     
$ 		The root object/element
@ 		The current object/element
. or [] 		Child operator
n/a 		Parent operator
.. 		Recursive descent. JSONPath borrows this syntax from E4X.
* 		Wildcard. All objects/elements regardless of their names.
n/a 		Attribute access. JSON structures do not have attributes.
[] 		Subscript operator. XPath uses it to iterate over element collections and for predicates. In Javascript and JSON it is the native array operator.
[,] 		Union operator in XPath results in a combination of node sets. JSONPath allows alternate names or array indices as a set.
[start\:end\:step] 	Array slice operator borrowed from ES4.
?() 		Applies a filter (script) expression.
() 		Sript expression, using the underlying script engine.

2.Examples\:
The examples below use the following JSON string value\:
{
    "store"\: {
        "book"\: [
            {
                "category"\: "reference",
                "author"\: "Nigel Rees",
                "title"\: "Sayings of the Century",
                "price"\: 8.95
            },
            {
                "category"\: "fiction",
                "author"\: "Evelyn Waugh",
                "title"\: "Sword of Honour",
                "price"\: 12.99
            },
            {
                "category"\: "fiction",
                "author"\: "Herman Melville",
                "title"\: "Moby Dick",
                "isbn"\: "0-553-21311-3",
                "price"\: 8.99
            },
            {
                "category"\: "fiction",
                "author"\: "J. R. R. Tolkien",
                "title"\: "The Lord of the Rings",
                "isbn"\: "0-395-19395-8",
                "price"\: 22.99
            }
        ],
        "bicycle"\: {
            "color"\: "red",
            "price"\: null
        }
    },
    "expensive"\: "10"
}

JSONPath 			Result
------------                                                ---------
$.store.book[*].author 		The authors of all books in the store
$...author 			All authors\: ["Nigel Rees","Evelyn Waugh","Herman Melville","J. R. R. Tolkien"]
$.store.* 			All items in store, which are some books and a red bicycle.
$.store..price 		The price of everything in the store
$..book[2] 			The third book
$..book[(@.length-1)] or $..book[-1\:] 	The last book in order
$..book[0,1] or $..book[\:2] 	The first two books
$..book[?(@.isbn)] 		Filter all books with isbn number
$..book[?(@.price<10)] 		Filter all books wholse price is less than 10
$..* 			All Elements in XML document. All members of JSON structure. 
$.store.book[0]		Returns the details of the first book\: reference,Nigel Rees,Sayings of the Century,8.95
$.store.bicycle			Returns the details of the bicycle including null in JSON format\: {"color"\:"red","price"\:null}
flow.name: Create_JSON_Object

staticBinding.annotation: String representation of a JSON object. Objects in JSON are a collection of name value pairs separated by a colon and surrounded with curly brackets {}. The name must be a string value and the value can be a single string or any valid JSON object or array. Examples: {"one":1, "two":2}, {"one":{"a":"a","B":"B"}, "two":"two", "three":[1,2,3.4]}
The name of the new property to add to the JSON object. There is no rule as to which character to use. Examples: property1, some_property, another property
The value for the new property. This is interpreted as a string, no matter what the contents of the input. Examples: value, 1, [1,2,3]

String representation of a JSON object. Objects in JSON are a collection of name value pairs separated by a colon and surrounded with curly brackets {}. The name must be a string value and the value can be a single string or any valid JSON object or array. Examples: {"one":1, "two":2}, {"one":{"a":"a","B":"B"}, "two":"two", "three":[1,2,3.4]}
